questions.question: Question 1: What are the specialized multinucleated macrophages in bone called?
questions.explanation:
Osteoclasts are specialized multinucleated macrophages derived from circulating monocytes that 
are responsible for bone resorption. Osteocytes are formed when osteoblasts are embedded in the matrix within lacunae and 
canaliculi. They control calcium and phosphate levels in the microenvironment. Osteoblasts are mesenchymal cells that rim the bony spicule, responsible for bone synthesis and 
mineralization. Chondrocytes are specialized cells that produce and maintain the extracellular matrix of cartilage. The image given below shows different cells present in a bone.
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a marker of bone resorption?
questions.explanation:
Osteocalcin is not a bone resorption marker. It is a protein secreted only by osteoblasts. Thus, it is a bone formation marker (osteoblastic 
marker). 1222 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is the most common benign bone tumor?
questions.explanation:
Osteochondroma, also known as exostosis, is the most common benign bone tumor. It is a benign cartilage-capped tumor. 85% of osteochondromas are solitary. The remainder is 
seen as part of the multiple hereditary exostosis syndromes, an autosomal-dominant hereditary 
disease. Lesions arise from the metaphysis near the growth plate of long tubular bones, especially near the 
knee. They are either sessile or pedunculated and range in size from 1 to 20 cm. Histologically, the 
cap is composed of benign hyaline cartilage varying in thickness and is covered peripherally by 
perichondrium. Osteochondromas can progress to chondrosarcoma. The image below shows the histopathological specimen of osteochondroma, displaying a cartilage 
cap lined by perichondrium contiguous with mature bone.
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 4: A woman delivered a child who died a few minutes after birth. The infant was found to have 
blue sclera and fractures of the right humerus, ulna, and femur at birth. What is the most 
probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta type II. The type II variant of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is uniformly fatal in utero or during the 
perinatal period. Type II OI is characterized by extraordinary bone fragility with multiple 
intrauterine fractures. Osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease) is caused by deficiencies in the synthesis of type I 
collagen. It can be separated into four major clinical subtypes that vary widely in severity. The 
severity of the disease is based on the location of the mutation within the protein. Individuals with type I OI have a normal life span, but experience childhood fractures that 
decrease in frequency following puberty. 1223 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 5: A 29-year-old woman gives birth to an infant with less than 5th percentile length. The head 
and torso are of normal size but extremities are short. The head circumference is at the 95th 
percentile, and frontal bossing is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This given clinical scenario is suggestive of achondroplasia. Achondroplasia is the most common skeletal dysplasia and a major cause of dwarfism. It has 
autosomal dominant inheritance. It occurs due to the gain of mutation in fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR3). This leads to 
abnormal cartilage proliferation at growth plates and affects endochondral bone growth. Infants 
present with: • Short stature • Rhizomelic shortening of limbs • Frontal bossing • Midface deficiency The condition is not associated with changes in longevity, intelligence, or reproductive status. The image below shows a baby affected with achondroplasia. Note the prominent forehead, 
triangular face, and body asymmetry in the image (a); a low nasal bridge in the image (b); trident 
hands in the image (c); and scoliosis in the image (d).
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is also called marble bone disease?
questions.explanation:
Albers-Schönberg disease or osteopetrosis is also known as marble bone disease. The term osteopetrosis reflects the stone-like quality of the bones. The bones are abnormally 
brittle and fracture easily, like a piece of chalk. It occurs due to reduced bone resorption and 
diffuse symmetric skeletal sclerosis because of impaired formation or function of osteoclasts. 1224 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Osteogenesis imperfecta is also called brittle bone disease. Paget's disease is also called 
osteitis deformans; it presents with mosaic pattern of lamellar bone.
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 7: An infant is being evaluated for multiple fractures over the last 3 months. On examination, 
hydrocephaly, cranial nerve defects, and hepatosplenomegaly are noted. Imaging reveals 
generalized sclerosis and a bone-in-bone appearance. Which of the following is the most likely 
enzyme to be deficient in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteopetrosis. It occurs due to autosomal recessive 
defects in the gene for the enzyme carbonic anhydrase II. Carbonic anhydrase II is required by osteoclasts and renal tubular cells to generate protons from 
carbon dioxide and water (acidification). The absence of carbonic anhydrase II prevents 
osteoclasts from acidifying the resorption pit and dissolution of calcium hydroxyapatite within the 
bone matrix. It also blocks the acidification of urine by the renal tubular cells. This leads to 
reduced bone resorption and diffuse symmetric skeletal sclerosis. Due to deficient osteoclast activity, bones involved by osteopetrosis lack a medullary canal giving 
it a bone-in-bone appearance. The ends of long bones are bulbous (Erlenmeyer flask deformity) 
and misshapen. The neural foramina are small and compress the exiting nerves, leading to cranial 
nerve palsies. Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis leads to leukopenia and prominent 
hepatosplenomegaly. As carbonic anhydrase II is widely expressed, mutations of this gene result 
in a condition called marble brain disease or Guibaud-Vainsel syndrome.
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 8: 1214 
Sold by @itachibot A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with sudden severe back pain. There is no 
history of trauma. X-ray findings are given below. MRI shows thinning of trabecular plates of 
the vertebrae and vertebral collapse. Levels of which of the following will be increased in her 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoporosis. Cytokines stimulate osteoclast 
recruitment and activity in osteoporosis by increasing the levels of RANKL. RANKL helps in diminishing the expression of osteoprotegerin (OPG), increasing osteoclast 
proliferation, and preventing osteoclast apoptosis. Decreased estrogen levels after menopause actually increase both bone resorption and formation. 
However, the latter does not keep up with the former, leading to a high turnover. Decreased 
estrogen appears to increase the secretion of inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6, TNF-, and 
IL-1.
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question: Question 9: In patients with which of the following conditions will you see a histologically normal bone?
questions.explanation:
Histologically normal bone with decreased density is the hallmark feature of osteoporosis. In advanced osteoporosis, both the trabecular bone of the medulla and the cortical bone are 
markedly thinned leading to progressive microfractures. 1225 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Inadequate mineralization in osteomalacia leads to a thickened osteoid matrix. Option C: Paget's disease presents with a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone. Option D: Dissecting osteitis cystica is seen in severe hyperparathyroidism.
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient presents with back pain, recurrent headaches, and increasing head size. On 
evaluation, raised alkaline phosphatase and a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone is seen. Which 
of the following statements is false about this condition? 1215 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: It occurs due to mutations in the SQSTM1 gene
options.c: It is polyostotic in about 15% of cases
options.d: Sarcoma occurs in less than 1% of all individuals

questions.explanation:
Paget disease is monostotic in about 15% of cases and polyostotic in the rest of them. Paget disease (osteitis deformans) is a disorder of increased, but disordered and structurally 
unsound, bone mass. The onset is in late adulthood (average age at diagnosis, 70 years). It occurs due to mutations in the SQSTM1 gene. This increases the activity of NF-B, which 
then increases osteoclast activity. Three sequential phases exist: • Initial osteolytic stage • Mixed osteoclastic-osteoblastic stage • Final burned-out quiescent osteosclerotic stage The axial skeleton or proximal femur is involved in up to 80% of the cases. The typical x-ray 
findings are as follows: • Enlargement of the craniofacial skeleton: leontiasis ossea or lion face • Invagination of the skull base (platybasia) • Chalk stick-type fractures in the long bones of the lower extremities The pathological hallmark is a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone, seen in the sclerotic phase as 
shown below. It shows a jigsaw-like pattern produced by unusually prominent cement lines, which 
join haphazardly oriented units of lamellar bone. 1226 
Sold by @itachibot Laboratory findings show elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and urinary hydroxyproline 
(normal serum calcium and phosphorus). Following tumors can develop in the affected bones in Paget's disease: • Benign tumors - • Giant cell tumors • Giant cell reparative granuloma • Extra-osseous masses of hematopoietic tissue • Sarcoma (osteosarcoma or fibrosarcoma) - most dreaded complication. Occurs in < 1 % of 
all individuals with Paget disease, and in 5% to 10% of those with the severe polyostotic disease.

questions.question: Question 11: In patients with hyperparathyroidism, which of the following is least expected?
questions.explanation:
Osteopetrosis does not belong to the clinical spectrum of hyperparathyroidism. The features of hyperparathyroidism are as follows: • Osteitis fibrosa cystica • Osteopenia/osteoporosis • Hyperuricemia and gout • Pseudogout • Increased production of calcitriol • Dissecting osteitis and brown tumors • Nephrolithiasis • Hypophosphatemia • Anemia 1227 
Sold by @itachibot Hyperparathyroidism leads to significant skeletal changes related to unabated osteoclast 
activity. Increased osteoclast activity is most prominent in cortical bone, but the medullary bone 
is not spared. Osteoclasts may tunnel into and dissect centrally along the length of the trabeculae, 
creating the appearance of railroad tracks, diagnostic of dissecting osteitis. Generalised 
osteoporosis may be seen in the phalanges, vertebrae, and proximal femur. Brown tumor presents with bone loss leading to microfractures and secondary hemorrhages 
which causes influx of macrophages and ingrowth of reparative fibrous tissue. Generalized osteitis 
presents with increased bone cell activity, peri-trabecular fibrosis, and cystic brown tumors.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 7-year-old child presented with fever, pain, and swelling around the knee joint for 3 days. 
Lab investigations showed a WBC count of 23,500/mm3. An MRI was done, which 
demonstrated an intramedullary abscess of the proximal tibia. Which of the following is the 
most common causative organism of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of acute pyogenic osteomyelitis. Staphylococcus aureus is 
the most common cause of culture-positive pyogenic osteomyelitis. Osteomyelitis denotes inflammation of bone and marrow, almost always secondary to infection. 
Organisms may reach the bone by • Hematogenous spread • Extension from a contiguous site • Direct implantation The common causative organisms include: • Staphylococcus aureus - the most common cause overall • Pseudomonas aeruginosa - most common cause in IV drug abusers • Salmonella - common in patients of sickle cell anemia • Haemophilus influenzae - was a common causative organism in children, less common now due 
to vaccination • Streptococcus pyogenes - most common in neonates • Escherichia coli, Klebsiella- most common cause in patients with genitourinary tract infections
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 13: Patients with sickle cell disease are particularly susceptible to osteomyelitis caused by which 
of the following?
questions.explanation:
Salmonella enteritidis is commonly implicated in osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia. The common causative organisms include: • Staphylococcus aureus - the most common cause overall • Pseudomonas aeruginosa - most common cause in IV drug abusers • Salmonella - most common in patients of sickle cell anemia • Haemophilus influenzae - was a common causative organism in children, less common now due 
to vaccination • Streptococcus pyogenes - neonates 1228 
Sold by @itachibot • Escherichia coli, Klebsiella- most common cause in patients with genitourinary tract infections
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 14: 1216 
Sold by @itachibot A patient who is a known case of TB presents to the orthopedic OPD with a 4-month history 
of progressively worsening back pain. He also complains of fatigue and irregular fever for 2 
weeks. X-ray reveals lytic destruction of the anterior portion of the vertebral body and 
increased anterior wedging. All of the following are the complications of his condition except
questions.explanation:
The patient is most likely suffering from TB osteomyelitis. Brodie's abscess is not a complication 
of this condition. In tuberculous osteomyelitis, weight-bearing joints - spine (Pott's disease), hips, and knees, are 
most commonly affected. Complications of tuberculous osteomyelitis include: • Scoliosis or kyphosis (gibbus) • Neurologic deficits secondary to spinal cord and nerve compression leading to paraplegia - • Tuberculous arthritis • Sinus tract formation • Psoas abscess - may be due to paravertebral “cold” abscess • AA amyloidosis
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

Question 15: A 25-year-old man presents with back pain that is unresponsive to aspirin. Radiographs show 
a well-demarcated lesion in the posterior spine. A biopsy is done and the histopathological 
finding is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? [Image unavailable]
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoblastoma. Histopathology shows well-circumscribed lesions composed of randomly interconnecting 
trabeculae of woven bone that are prominently rimmed by a single layer of osteoblasts. Stroma 
surrounding the neoplastic bone consists of loose connective tissue that contains many dilated 
and congested capillaries. The image below shows the histopathological findings in osteoblastoma. 1229

questions.question:
Question 16: A 17-year-old man presents with progressive swelling of the upper end of the humerus. He 
also complains of arm pain and weight loss for 3 months. X-ray findings are given below. 
Which of the following is associated with a higher risk of developing this condition? 1217 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given history and classic sunburst appearance on the X-ray are highly suggestive of 
osteosarcoma. Mutation of p53 (Li-Fraumeni syndrome) is associated with a greater risk of 
sarcomas, particularly osteosarcoma. The image given below shows sunburst pattern seen in osteosarcoma. 1230 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Translocation (X;18) is characteristic of synovial sarcoma. Option B: Translocation (12;16) is characteristic of myxoid liposarcoma. Option D: 1p rearrangements are characteristic of conventional chondrosarcoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following statements is false about osteosarcoma?

options.a: It usually arises in the diaphyseal region of long bones
options.b: It has a bimodal age distribution
options.c: Codman triangle is characteristic of the tumor
options.d: Most common subtype is osteoblastic and high grade

questions.explanation:
Osteosarcomas usually arise in the metaphyseal region of the long bones of the extremities. It 
commonly occurs in the knee (i.e., distal femur or proximal tibia). The most common subtype is primary, intramedullary, osteoblastic, and high grade. It is a 
malignant tumor in which the cancerous cells produce an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. It 
occurs in all age groups but has a bimodal age distribution. The formation of fine lace-like neoplastic bone by the tumor cells is diagnostic histopathologically 
of osteosarcoma as shown below. 1231 
Sold by @itachibot Radiography shows a large destructive, mixed lytic and blastic mass with infiltrative margins, 
which breaks through the cortex and lifts the periosteum, resulting in reactive periosteal bone 
formation. The triangular shadow between the cortex and raised ends of the periosteum, known 
radiographically as the Codman triangle, is characteristic of osteosarcoma. This is shown in the 
radiograph below. 1232 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following bone tumors is characteristically seen in patients with Ollier disease 
and Maffucci syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ollier disease and Maffucci syndrome are nonhereditary disorders characterized by multiple 
enchondromas. Maffucci syndrome is, in addition, distinguished by the presence of spindle-cell 
hemangiomas. Enchondromas are benign tumors of hyaline cartilage that usually occur in bones of enchondral 
origin. They are usually diagnosed in individuals 20 to 50 years of age. They present as solitary 
metaphyseal lesions of tubular bones of the hands and feet. The radiographic features consist of circumscribed lucencies with central irregular calcifications, a 
sclerotic rim, and an intact cortex. They are usually smaller than 3 cm. They are gray-blue and 
translucent, composed of well-circumscribed nodules of hyaline cartilage containing 
cytomorphologically benign chondrocytes. The enchondromas in Ollier disease and Maffucci syndrome are sometimes more cellular than 
sporadic enchondromas and exhibit cytologic atypia, making them more difficult to distinguish 
from chondrosarcomas. The image below displays the histopathological picture of an enchondroma showing lobules of 
hyaline cartilage encased by bone and covered by perichondrium (fibrous tissue). 1233 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following statements is not true about chondrosarcoma?

options.a: Conventional central tumors constitute about 90% of chondrosarcomas.
options.b: Clear cell and the mesenchymal variants occur in older patients.
options.c: Chondrosarcomas commonly arise in the axial skeleton.
options.d: In multiple hereditary exostosis, osteochondromas progress to chondrosarcoma.

questions.explanation:
The clear cell and the mesenchymal variants of chondrosarcoma occur in younger patients (teens 
or 20s). Chondrosarcomas are malignant tumors that produce cartilage. They commonly arise in the axial 
skeleton, especially the pelvis, shoulder, and ribs. They are subclassified histologically as following variants: • Conventional (hyaline cartilage producing) - 90% cases • Clear cell • Dedifferentiated • Mesenchymal 1234 
Sold by @itachibot In multiple hereditary exostosis, osteochondromas can progress to chondrosarcoma. Increased 
thickness of the cartilage cap has been reported as an indicator of potential malignancy. The 
average age of secondary chondrosarcoma is younger than patients with primary tumors.
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following can progress to become chondrosarcoma?
questions.explanation:
Osteochondromas, multiple enchondromas, and synovial chondromatosis can progress to become 
chondrosarcoma. The average age of patients with secondary chondrosarcoma is 35 years (less than that of those 
with primary tumors). These tumors most commonly affect the pelvic bones. The increased 
thickness of the cartilage cap (normally 1–3 mm) is considered an indicator of potential 
malignancy. Multiple enchondromas in the setting of Ollier’s disease or Maffucci's syndrome carry a 
significantly higher risk of transformation to secondary chondrosarcoma than solitary 
enchondromas. Histological findings of abundant myxoid change, cyst formation, and permeation 
of existing trabeculae suggest malignancy. Secondary malignancy in synovial chondromatosis has been reported, but it is rare.
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 21: A plain radiograph of a patient shows a destructive lytic tumor that extends into the 
surrounding soft tissues with a characteristic onion-skin appearance. A biopsy image is shown 
below. Which of the following is not true about the tumor?

options.a: It is the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children
options.b: It arises in the epiphysis of long tubular bones
options.c: Most of these tumours contain a (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation
options.d: The amount of chemotherapy-induced necrosis is an important prognostic finding

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing sarcoma. It arises in the diaphysis of long bones, 
especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis. Ewing sarcoma follows osteosarcoma as the second most common group of bone sarcomas in 
children. It generally affects patients < 20 years. Boys are affected slightly more frequently than 
girls. Usually, the tumor arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and the 
flat bones of the pelvis. Fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis may be seen. Plain radiographs 
show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins that extend into the surrounding soft 
tissues. The characteristic periosteal reaction produces layers of reactive bone deposited in an 
onion-skin fashion. It arises in the medullary cavity and usually invades the cortex, periosteum, 
and soft tissue. On microscopy, sheets of uniform, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm are seen, which may 
appear clear because they are rich in glycogen. The presence of Homer–Wright rosettes indicates a 
greater degree of neuroectodermal differentiation. The image given below shows the histopathological findings in Ewing sarcoma. 1235 
Sold by @itachibot Most Ewing sarcoma family tumors contain an (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation. Variant 
translocations fuse the EWS to other members of the ETS transcription factor family. 
CD99(MIC2), FLI1, and NSE would be positive in ES/PNET.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of pain in the left knee, which is tender 
on palpation. X-ray shows a 5 cm mass in the distal femoral epiphysis, with a soap bubble 
appearance. Microscopy is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoclastoma/ giant-cell tumor (GCT) of bone. GCT is a relatively uncommon benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in 
individuals in their 20s to 40s. The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL. It promotes the 
proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts via RANK 
expressed by these cells. 1236 
Sold by @itachibot GCTs arise in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis. The majority arise around the 
knee (distal femur and proximal tibia). Most are solitary, multicentric tumors in the distal 
extremities. The tumors destroy the overlying cortex, producing a bulging soft tissue mass 
delineated by a thin shell of reactive tissue. Histopathologically, sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant 
cells are seen with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent. The image given below shows the histopathological findings seen in osteoclastoma. Typically, they are treated with curettage, but 40% to 60% recur locally. Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs, but these sometimes spontaneously regress and they 
are rarely fatal. The RANKL inhibitor, denosumab, has shown promise as adjuvant therapy in 
GCT. Note: The E mnemonic for GCT: • Epiphyseal 1237 
Sold by @itachibot • Eccentric • Egg-shell crackling • Expansile
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 23: A 19-year old man presents with back pain for 2 months. MRI of the spine reveals a bony 
cystic mass at the L1 vertebra. Biopsy shows multiple, blood-filled cystic spaces separated by 
septae, composed of multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells and reactive woven bone. There 
is no cartilage or necrosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an aneurysmal bone cyst. It affects all age groups, but generally occurs during the first 2 decades of life and has no sex 
predilection. It usually occurs in the metaphysis of long bones and the posterior elements of 
vertebral bodies. This is a tumor characterized by multiloculated blood-filled cystic spaces separated by septae, 
composed of multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells and reactive woven bone. Radiographically, 
an aneurysmal bone cyst is seen as an eccentric, expansile, lesion with well-defined margins. Most 
lesions are completely lytic and often contain a thin shell of reactive bone at the periphery. The spindle cells of aneurysmal bone cyst frequently demonstrate rearrangements of chromosome 
17p13, leading to USP6 overexpression. The majority of secondary aneurysmal bone cysts arise in association with: • Benign neoplasms • Giant-cell tumor of the bone (most common) • Chondroblastoma • Osteoblastoma • Fibrous dysplasia • Osteosarcoma
questions.chapter_heading: Developmental disorders infections and tumors o

questions.question:
Question 24: A 60-year-old patient complains of severe back pain for 2 months, which worsens at night. An 
MRI shows multiple osteoblastic secondaries on the vertebrae. Which of the following tumors 
could be the primary source of these lesions?
questions.explanation:
Prostatic adenocarcinoma is associated with predominantly osteoblastic secondaries to the bones 
(vertebral column). The radiographic appearance of bone metastases may be purely lytic (bone destroying), purely 
blastic (bone-forming), or mixed lytic and blastic. Most cancers are associated with predominantly 
one pattern or the other. Parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) and transforming growth factor- (TGF- ) are 
implicated in osteolytic secondaries, while proteins such as endothelin-1 and morphogenetic 
proteins are implicated in osteoblastic lesions. 1238 
Sold by @itachibot Joints and soft tissue pathology
